G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 (granting jurisdiction to the Superior Court in civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000).

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Bristol County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions giving rise to this complaint occurred within this county.

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a duty of reasonable care exists where one undertakes the supervision of children, particularly when representing that professional childcare or after‑school supervision will be provided.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address duties arising from undertaking supervision of children or holding oneself out as providing professional childcare or after‑school supervision. Instead, it concerns whether an employer of an ex‑offender owed a duty to a member of the general public, and the court expressly finds no duty in these circumstances. There is no discussion of childcare, supervision of minors, or a special duty based on such an undertaking, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt:
“Here, the victim was neither a customer of Titus & Bean, nor an employee or business invitee at the time she was murdered. Furthermore, at the time that Kelly committed the murder, he had not started to work that day.

Our analysis does not stop here. A special relationship between the parties may give rise to a common-law duty. … Here, the motion judge ruled that Titus & Bean did not have a duty to perform a background check on Kelley’s prior criminal acts because it was not reasonably foreseeable that he would attack a member of the public.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: This duty arises under common-law principles of negligence and the standard of reasonable care codified and recognized in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983), which holds that institutions undertaking supervision of minors must take reasonable precautions to protect them from foreseeable harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted text is a dissent focused entirely on causation, not on defining or affirming any duty of reasonable care toward minors. While the majority opinion in Mullins does recognize a duty of institutions to take reasonable precautions against foreseeable criminal acts, this dissent neither discusses that duty nor frames it in terms of supervision of minors. Because the provided passage does not address the duty element at all, it cannot itself be cited as authority for the proposition stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving 'that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.' Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982)."

Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 M.raw_text: Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 Mass. 491 (1994)
Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 M.proposition: Under Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 Mass. 491 (1994), one who undertakes the protection of others and fails to do so adequately is subject to tort liability if injury results that was reasonably foreseeable.
Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 M.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a commercial damages and causation analysis in a business tort/Chapter 93A context; it does not discuss the tort principle that one who undertakes the protection of others and performs negligently is liable for foreseeable injury. There is no mention of an assumed duty to protect, failure to protect, or foreseeability of personal injury. The proposition described is a general negligent undertaking rule (Restatement (Second) of Torts § 323/324A type), which this case neither states nor applies.
Fiorentino v. Probate Court Dept., 417 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs had to prove that Isotronics sustained monetary losses due to the defendants’ wrongdoing… Damages for lost profits are recoverable only when proof is made ‘with sufficient certainty.’ … The problem with the judge’s decision is that his conclusion concerning damages is not supported by his underlying findings.”

Barnett v. Lynn, 433 Mass. 662 (2001).proposition: The assault or rough play that caused Plaintiff’s child’s injury was a foreseeable risk of neglecting adequate supervision, as recognized in Barnett v. Lynn, 433 Mass. 662 (2001) and Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 688 (1997).
Barnett v. Lynn, 433 Mass. 662 (2001).support_reasoning: Barnett v. Lynn concerns municipal immunity under the discretionary function exception and the open-and-obvious danger doctrine, not foreseeability of assault or rough play due to negligent supervision. The court analyzes whether decisions about fencing, snow removal, and warning signs are discretionary policy choices and whether there was a duty to warn, but it does not address risks of assault, horseplay, or supervision of children. Thus it does not support the stated proposition about foreseeability of assault or rough play as a risk of inadequate supervision.
Barnett v. Lynn, 433 Mass. 662 (2001).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff argues that the failure to post warning signs in this case does not rise to the level of policymaking or planning. We need not resolve this question, however, because the danger of sledding down the snow-covered stairs was open and obvious. ‘Landowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises because it is not reasonably foreseeable that a visitor exercising (as the law presumes) reasonable care for his own safety would suffer injury from such blatant hazards.’”

Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 6.raw_text: Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 688 (1997)
Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 6.proposition: The assault or rough play that caused Plaintiff’s child’s injury was a foreseeable risk of neglecting adequate supervision, as recognized in Barnett v. Lynn, 433 Mass. 662 (2001) and Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 688 (1997).
Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Andres v. Town of Waterboro at all, but a criminal case (Commonwealth v. Anderson) dealing with reasonable doubt instructions, voluntariness of confessions, and duplicative convictions for felony-murder and the underlying felony. It does not involve supervision of children, foreseeability of assault or rough play, or any negligence/supervision issues. Accordingly, it cannot support the proposition about foreseeable risks of inadequate supervision causing injury to a child.
Andres v. Town of Waterboro, 425 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: We summarize the facts as the jurors could have found them, in the light most favorable to the Commonwealth. Commonwealth v. Sanna, 424 Mass. 92, 93 (1997). On December 10, 1974, at approximately 4 p.m., the victim’s fifteen year old son was tending the cash register in the victim’s shoe repair shop in the Roxbury section of Boston when the defendant, one Jerry Funderberg, and a man known as “Pabst” entered the shop.... [discussion of robbery and murder].

Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..raw_text: Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988)
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable supervision recognized in Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988) (holding that establishments owe a duty to protect invitees from foreseeable harm resulting from third-party acts).
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case recognizes and applies the tort of negligent hiring/retention, imposing on employers whose employees interact with the public a duty to use reasonable care in selecting and retaining employees who will not endanger invitees. However, it does not articulate a broad premises-liability duty to protect invitees from all foreseeable third‑party acts in the way the proposition suggests. The duty discussed is narrower and tied specifically to the employer’s own negligence in hiring/retaining an unfit employee, not a general duty to protect invitees from third-party conduct.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The doctrine states that an employer whose employees are brought in contact with members of the public in the course of the employer’s business has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of his employees. ‘An employer must use due care to avoid the selection or retention of an employee whom he knows or should know is a person unworthy, by habits, temperament, or nature, to deal with the persons invited to the premises by the employer.’ … In these circumstances it was open to the jury to find that Loft was negligent in retaining Rida in his position as bartender….”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85X.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that a parent may recover medical expenses and loss of the child’s services under G.L. c. 231, § 85X, and health care providers may recover through this section when negligence of others causes injury to a minor.

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to follow its own safety policies and its misrepresentations regarding continuous supervision constitute additional evidence of breach.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The decision does not treat violation of the hospital’s own escort policy or any alleged representations about supervision as additional evidence of breach. Instead, the court assumes arguendo possible negligence and resolves the case on absence of duty and lack of proximate cause, expressly declining to ground liability on a voluntarily assumed duty. Thus, it does not support the proposition that failing to follow internal safety policies or misrepresenting supervision constitutes additional evidence of breach.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Leavitt’s de minimis argument as to the third theory — that the hospital voluntarily assumed a duty of care to nonpatient third parties — lacks merit. A similar argument was rejected in Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182 (2007), and Leavitt provides no reason for us to revisit it.… [T]he hospital owed no duty to Leavitt to control or detain the patient.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest from the date of the filing of this Complaint.
